p: Chikungunya virus (CHIKV) is a mosquito-borne virus, member of the Alphavirus genus of the Togaviridae family, causing acute febrile illness in affected people that can develop to chronic debilitating polyarthralgia and polyarthritis. This arboviral pathogen, that was identified in the former Tanganyika territory in 1952 [ 1, 2], caused repeated epidemics in Africa and Asia from the 1960sâ€“1980s [ 3, 4]. The following decades were of relative inactivity, but CHIKV re-emerged in 2005 causing in the French overseas department of Reunion and other Indian Ocean islands a fiery epidemic with more than 700,000 patients and 250 deaths [ 4]. The next year, in another massive outbreak in India, several million people were affected by CHIKV [ 5]. In the last years, this virus has spread quickly [ 6], causing numerous outbreaks in both tropical and subtropical countries around the world with increasing severity [ 7, 8]. In addition, several CHIKV outbreaks in Europe, mainly in Italy, have been reported recently [ 9]. Therefore, infection by this virus is a serious threat to global health, and CHIKV is at present considered a high priority emerging pathogen [ 10].
